Question: What does HTML stand for?
Rationale: HTML is the standard language for creating the structure of web pages.

Question: Which tag is the root element of any HTML page?
Rationale: The <html> tag wraps all content on the entire page.

Question: What is the purpose of the <!DOCTYPE html> declaration?
Option A: It defines the title of the document.
Option B: It tells the browser what version of HTML the page is written in.
Rationale: <!DOCTYPE> is an instruction that helps the browser render the page correctly.

Question: Which element contains all the meta-information and links for an HTML document?
Rationale: The <head> element is a container for metadata and is placed between the <html> and <body> tags.

Question: What is the main purpose of the <body> tag?
Option B: To contain all the visible content of a web page.
Option D: To define a section of the document.
Rationale: Everything visible to the user—headings, paragraphs, images—goes inside the <body>.

Question: Which tag is used to define the title that appears in the browser tab?
Rationale: The text inside the <title> tag is displayed on the browser's title bar or tab.

Question: How do you write a comment in HTML?
Rationale: HTML comments are not displayed by the browser and are useful for notes in the code.

Question: What does the 'charset' attribute in <meta charset="UTF-8"> specify?
Option A: The character set for the HTML document.
Rationale: UTF-8 is a universal character set that includes almost all characters from human languages.

Question: Which element is considered the main heading of a page?
Rationale: <h1> should be used for the main title of a page's content, and there should generally only be one.

Question: How do you link an external CSS file to an HTML document?
Rationale: The <link> tag, placed in the <head>, is the correct way to link to external style sheets.

Question: Which of these is NOT a valid tag?
Rationale:
The tag for a paragraph is

, not .

Question: What is the function of a browser's rendering engine?
Option B: To parse HTML and CSS and display the formatted content.
Rationale: The rendering engine (like Blink or Gecko) turns the code you write into a visual webpage.

Question: Which tag creates a simple paragraph of text?
Rationale: stands for 'paragraph' and is the standard tag for text blocks.

Question: Where in the HTML document should the <title> tag be placed?
Rationale: The <title> is metadata and belongs in the <head> section.

Question: What is a favicon?
Option B: A small icon displayed in the browser tab.
Rationale: A favicon helps brand your website and makes it recognizable in a list of browser tabs.

Question:
How do you properly close the

tag?
Option D: It doesn't need to be closed.
Rationale:
Most HTML tags come in pairs with an opening and a closing tag (e.g.,

and

).

Question: Which of these tags is a 'container' for other tags?
Rationale: A <div> (division) is a generic container used to group other elements.

Question: An HTML file must be saved with which extension?
Rationale: Browsers recognize .html or .htm files as web pages.

Question: What is the purpose of the <meta name="viewport"> tag?
Option B: To control the page's dimensions and scaling for different devices.
Rationale: The viewport meta tag is crucial for creating responsive websites that look good on mobile devices.

Question: True or False: HTML is a programming language.
Rationale: HTML is a markup language, used for structuring content, not for performing logic like a programming language.

Question: What is the correct structure of a basic HTML5 document?
Rationale: A valid HTML5 document starts with the doctype, followed by the html, head, and body tags in order.

Question: How do you link a JavaScript file named 'script.js' to your HTML?
Rationale: The <script> tag is used to embed or refer to executable scripts.

Question: What is the default character encoding for HTML5?
Rationale: UTF-8 is the standard and recommended character encoding for HTML5.

Question: A webpage can have multiple <body> tags.
Rationale: An HTML document can only have one <body> tag.

Question: What does 'rendering' mean in the context of a browser?
Option A: Sending a file to the printer.
Option B: Translating code into a visual webpage.
Rationale: Rendering is the process of drawing the text, images, and other elements on the screen.

Question: Which tag would you use to create the largest heading?
Rationale: <h1> represents the most important heading, and browsers display it with the largest default font size.

Question: How do you create an unordered list (a bulleted list)?
Rationale: <ul> stands for 'unordered list' and uses <li> for each list item.

Question: Which tag is used to emphasize text, often displayed in italics by default?
Rationale: <em> stands for 'emphasis' and indicates semantic importance. While it looks italic, the meaning is what's key.

Question: What is the purpose of the 'alt' attribute on an tag?
Option A: To provide a caption for the image.
Option B: To provide alternative text for screen readers or if the image fails to load.
Option C: To set the alignment of the image.
Option D: To link the image to another page.
Rationale: 'alt' text is crucial for accessibility and SEO.

Question: Which tag is used for creating an ordered list (a numbered list)?
Rationale: <ol> stands for 'ordered list' and automatically numbers its <li> items.

Question: Which tag is used to define a single item within a list?
Rationale: <li> stands for 'list item' and is used within both <ul> and <ol>.

Question: How do you display a video file named 'movie.mp4' on a webpage?
Rationale: The <video> tag is the standard way to embed video content.

Question: To make video or audio controls visible to the user, what attribute should you add?
Rationale: The boolean 'controls' attribute adds play, pause, and volume controls.

Question: Which tag represents text that is 'strongly important' and is usually displayed as bold?
Rationale: <strong> indicates that its content has strong importance, seriousness, or urgency.

Question: How do you insert an image named 'logo.png' into a page?
Rationale: The tag is used for images, and the 'src' attribute points to the image file. 'alt' text should always be included.

Question: What is the purpose of the <blockquote> tag?
Option B: To define a section that is quoted from another source.
Option D: To create a list of quotes.
Rationale: <blockquote> is used for longer, block-level quotations.

Question: Can you put a <ul> inside another <ul>?
Option A: Yes, to create a nested list.
Option C: Only if you use a <ol> in between.
Option D: Only if you use a <div> wrapper.
Rationale: Nesting lists is a common and valid way to create sub-items.

Question: Which tag is used to display a block of computer code?
Rationale: <code> is for inline code, while <pre> preserves whitespace for code blocks. Both are often used together.

Question: What is the difference between <b> and <strong>?
Option B: <b> is for bolding, <strong> is for italics.
Option C: <b> is a style element, while <strong> is a semantic element indicating importance.
Rationale: While they look the same, <strong> gives the text semantic meaning, which is better for accessibility.

Question: Which element should you use to provide multiple sources for a video for browser compatibility?
Rationale: The <source> tag can be placed inside a <video> or <audio> element to specify multiple media files.

Question: What does the <hr> tag do?
Option A: Creates a heading row in a table.
Option B: Defines a horizontal rule or thematic break.
Rationale: The <hr> tag creates a horizontal line, often used to separate content.

Question: Which of these is NOT a valid heading tag?
Rationale: Heading tags only go from <h1> to <h6>.

Question: The <audio> tag is used for...
Rationale: Similar to the <video> tag, <audio> is for embedding sounds.

Question: What is the primary benefit of using the <picture> element?
Option A: It lets you add a border to an image.
Option B: It allows you to provide different image sources based on screen size or device capabilities.
Option C: It groups multiple pictures into a gallery.
Rationale: The <picture> element gives developers more flexibility in specifying image resources for responsive designs.

Question: Which element would you use to define an abbreviation or an acronym, like 'HTML'?
Rationale: The <abbr> tag can be used with a 'title' attribute to show the full expansion on hover.

Question: How would you create a list that starts at the number 5?
Rationale: The 'start' attribute on an <ol> tag specifies the starting value of the first item.

Question: Which attribute is required for an tag to be valid?
Rationale: The 'src' (source) attribute is mandatory as it specifies the path to the image to be displayed.

Question: What is the semantic meaning of the <em> tag?
Option B: It marks text that has stress emphasis.
Option D: It defines a small piece of code.
Rationale: 'em' stands for emphasis. Screen readers may use a different tone of voice for text within this tag.

Question: To play a video file automatically when the page loads, which attribute should you use?
Rationale: The 'autoplay' attribute will start the video automatically. Note: Many browsers now block autoplay with sound.

Question: Which element creates a line break?
Rationale:
The
tag inserts a single line break and is an empty tag (it has no closing tag).

Question: Which tag is used to create a hyperlink?
Rationale: The <a> tag, which stands for 'anchor', is used to define hyperlinks.

Question: Which attribute of the <a> tag specifies the URL of the page the link goes to?
Rationale: 'href' stands for 'hypertext reference' and contains the destination address.

Question: How do you create a link that opens in a new browser tab?
Rationale: target="_blank" instructs the browser to open the link in a new tab or window.

Question: What is an 'anchor link'?
Option A: A link that downloads a file.
Option B: A link to an external website.
Option C: A link that jumps to a specific section on the same page.
Rationale: Anchor links are used for navigating within a single document.

Question: To create an anchor link, what attribute must you first add to the destination element?
Rationale: You give the destination element a unique 'id', like <h2 id="section2">.

Question: How would you create a link that points to an element with id="C4"?
Rationale: The '#' symbol followed by the id value is used in the href to target an anchor.

Question: What is the purpose of the 'rel="nofollow"' attribute on a link?
Option A: It prevents the link from being clicked.
Option B: It tells search engines not to follow or pass authority to the linked page.
Option C: It opens the link in a new tab.
Option D: It makes the link's text bold.
Rationale: 'nofollow' is an instruction for search engine crawlers.

Question: How do you create a link that starts composing an email to 'test@example.com'?
Rationale: The 'mailto:' URI scheme is used to create links that open the user's default email client.

Question: What is an 'internal link'?
Option A: A link to a section on the same page.
Option B: A link to another page on the same website.
Option C: A link that only works inside a company's network.
Option D: A link to an external website.
Rationale: Internal links connect pages within the same domain.

Question: What is an 'external link'?
Option A: A link to an outside website (a different domain).
Option B: A link to an image file.
Option C: A link that opens in the same tab.
Option D: A link that is styled with CSS.
Rationale: External links point to resources on other websites.

Question: Which of these creates a valid link to Google's homepage?
Rationale: This shows the correct use of the <a> tag and its 'href' attribute.

Question: What does the target="_self" attribute do?
Option A: Opens the link in a new window.
Option B: Opens the link in the parent frame.
Option C: Opens the link in the same window/tab (this is the default).
Rationale: '_self' is the default behavior, so you usually don't need to specify it.

Question: A navigation bar in HTML is typically created using...
Option A: A <nav> tag containing an unordered list (<ul>) of links.
Option D: A <table> with links in each cell.
Rationale: Using a <nav> element with a list of <a> tags is the semantically correct way to create a navigation menu.

Question: How would you link to a page named 'about.html' that is in the same directory?
Rationale: A filename by itself, or prefixed with './', refers to a file in the current directory.

Question: What is a 'dead' or 'broken' link?
Option A: A link to a page that no longer exists (a 404 error).
Option B: A link that hasn't been styled with CSS.
Option C: A link to a PDF file.
Option D: A link that doesn't use the 'href' attribute.
Rationale: A broken link points to a resource that cannot be found.

Question: The text between the opening and closing tags is called...
Option A: The link text or anchor text.
Rationale: This is the clickable part of the hyperlink that is visible to the user.

Question: How can you make an image into a link?
Rationale: You wrap the tag inside an tag to make the entire image clickable.

Question: To link to a specific part of 'page2.html' with an id of 'summary', what would the href be?
Rationale: You use the page name followed by a '#' and the id.

Question: What is the purpose of a 'sitemap'?
Option A: It's a page that contains only images.
Option B: It's a visual design of the website.
Option C: It's an HTML page that contains links to all other pages on your site, helping with navigation.
Option D: It's a map showing the server location.
Rationale: A sitemap provides a structural overview and easy access to all parts of a website.

Question: Is it possible to link to a phone number to start a call on mobile devices?
Option D: No, this is not possible with HTML.
Rationale: The 'tel:' URI scheme allows users to initiate a phone call by clicking a link.

Question: Which tag is used to create an HTML form?
Rationale: The <form> element is a container for all the input elements.

Question: What is the purpose of the <label> tag?
Option A: To add a title to the form.
Option B: To describe an input element, improving accessibility and usability.
Option C: To create a large text input area.
Rationale: Clicking on a <label> focuses its corresponding input field.

Question: Which input 'type' creates a single-line text field?
Rationale: type="text" is the most common input field for names, usernames, etc.

Question: How do you create a button that submits the form data?
Rationale: Both <input type="submit"> and <button type="submit"> create a submit button for a form.

Question: Which input 'type' is used for selecting one choice from many?
Rationale: Radio buttons in the same 'name' group are mutually exclusive.

Question: Which attribute is used to associate a <label> with an <input> element?
Option B: The 'for' attribute on the label and the 'id' on the input.
Rationale: For example, <label for="user"> and <input id="user"> are linked.

Question: What does the 'placeholder' attribute do?
Option A: It provides the default value for the input.
Option B: It provides a short hint or example text that appears in the field before the user enters a value.
Option D: It pre-fills the form with data.
Rationale: Placeholder text disappears as soon as the user starts typing.

Question: Which element creates a dropdown list?
Rationale: The <select> tag is used with <option> tags inside it to create the choices.

Question: Which input 'type' allows for selecting zero or more choices from a list?
Rationale: Checkboxes allow users to select multiple options in a set.

Question: To make an input field mandatory, which attribute should you use?
Rationale: 'required' is a boolean attribute that enforces the user to fill out the field before submitting.

Question: What is the purpose of the 'name' attribute on an <input> tag?
Option A: It is an identifier for CSS styling.
Option B: It provides a name for the data when it is sent to the server.
Option C: It's a replacement for the 'id' attribute.
Option D: It specifies the input's visible label.
Rationale: When a form is submitted, the data is sent as name/value pairs.

Question: Which element is used to group related elements in a form, often drawing a box around them?
Rationale: <fieldset> helps to organize long forms into logical sections.

Question: What is the purpose of the <legend> tag?
Option A: It defines the main title of the webpage.
Option B: It provides a caption or title for a <fieldset>.
Rationale: A <legend> should be the first child of the <fieldset> it describes.

Question: Which input 'type' is specifically designed for entering email addresses?
Rationale: type="email" provides automatic validation in supporting browsers to check for an '@' symbol.

Question: How do you create a multi-line text input for comments or messages?
Rationale: The <textarea> tag provides a large, resizable text box.

Question: What is the purpose of the 'action' attribute on a <form> tag?
Option A: It specifies where to send the form data when the form is submitted.
Option B: It defines the animation to play on submit.
Option C: It specifies which script to run on the client-side.
Rationale: The 'action' attribute usually contains a URL to a server-side script.

Question: Which input 'type' is best for entering a password?
Rationale: type="password" masks the input, showing dots or asterisks instead of the actual characters.

Question: What is the 'value' attribute used for on an <input> tag?
Option A: To provide a hint like placeholder.
Option B: To set the initial/default value of the field.
Rationale: For a submit button, it defines the text on the button. For a text field, it's the pre-filled content.

Question: To set a default choice in a dropdown list, what attribute do you use on the <option> tag?
Rationale: The 'selected' attribute pre-selects an option in a <select> list.

Question: Which attribute can be used to specify a regular expression that the input's value must match?
Rationale: The 'pattern' attribute allows for powerful custom validation on text-based inputs.

Question: What does ARIA stand for in the context of web accessibility?
Rationale: ARIA provides extra attributes to make web content more accessible to people with disabilities.

Question: Which element would define one choice in a dropdown list?
Rationale: <option> tags are placed inside a <select> element.

Question: How do you ensure a set of radio buttons are mutually exclusive?
Option B: Give them all the same 'name' attribute.
Rationale: Only one radio button with the same 'name' can be selected at a time.

Question: Which input 'type' creates a field for entering a date?
Rationale: type="date" provides a date-picker interface in supporting browsers.

Question: What is client-side form validation?
Option A: Validation that happens on the server after submission.
Option B: Validation that happens in the browser before the form is submitted.
Option D: Validation that checks the user's internet speed.
Rationale: HTML5 attributes like 'required' and 'pattern' perform client-side validation.

Question: The <input type="hidden"> is used for...
Option C: Submitting data that is not visible to the user.
Option D: A field that is temporarily disabled.
Rationale: Hidden inputs are useful for sending tracking data or security tokens with a form.

Question: How can you pre-check a checkbox by default?
Rationale: The boolean 'checked' attribute will make a checkbox or radio button selected on page load.

Question: What is the purpose of the 'for' attribute on a <label>?
Option A: It specifies which form the label belongs to.
Option B: It links the label to its corresponding input element via the input's 'id'.
Rationale: This improves usability, as clicking the label will focus or activate the input.

Question: Which input attribute limits the number of characters allowed in a text field?
Rationale: For example, maxlength="10" would allow no more than 10 characters.

Question: Which HTTP method is typically used by forms to submit data?
Rationale: GET appends data to the URL, while POST sends it in the request body. POST is used for sensitive or large data.
